content:
America’s government shutdown becomes the longest ever on January 12th

BETWEEN APRIL 26th 2010 and December 6th 2011—a span of 589 days—<span class="word-wrap-span">Belgiumspan> had no elected government. Tensions between its Dutch and French-speaking <span class="word-wrap-span">residentspan>s meant that the country’s 12 political parties were unable to <span class="word-wrap-span">brokerspan> a deal on who would govern. During the <span class="word-wrap-span">impassespan>, a “<span class="word-wrap-span">caretakerspan>” <span class="word-wrap-span">coalitionspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">presidespan>d over the country, money still flowed to agencies and the government remained <span class="word-wrap-span">functionalspan>. As the United States shutdown becomes the longest in history—it enters its 22nd day on Jan 12th—some Americans are wondering whether theirs is the only country that deals with a <span class="word-wrap-span">gridlockspan> so severe that large <span class="word-wrap-span">portionspan>s of its government <span class="word-wrap-span">ceasespan> to operate. Their suspicions are correct. 

There are several reasons why America is unique in this way. First, there is its <span class="word-wrap-span">peculiarspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">presidespan>ntial system of democracy, which increases the chance that any given <span class="word-wrap-span">legislationspan> will fail to become law. A single bill must receive <span class="word-wrap-span">assentspan> from the House, <span class="word-wrap-span">Senatespan>, and <span class="word-wrap-span">presidespan>nt. Because Americans vote for members of those branches of government separately, the branches are often led by different parties with different priorities. <span class="word-wrap-span">presidespan>nt Donald Trump is demanding that funding be provided for a border wall before the government is funded; the <span class="word-wrap-span">Democraticspan>-led House of Representatives is refusing. <span class="word-wrap-span">Parliamentaryspan> governments, by contrast, can pass spending bills with simple majorities. Because there are not mid-term elections that could give a prime minister or <span class="word-wrap-span">chancellorspan>’s party a sudden minority in the <span class="word-wrap-span">legislaturespan> little gets in the way of <span class="word-wrap-span">legislationspan> that enjoys sup<span class="word-wrap-span">porspan>t from the majority.

The process of funding the government is also different in America. Spending bills in the United States are <span class="word-wrap-span">mammothspan> affairs, with the 2018 bill spanning almost 900 pages. These bills are passed yearly and only fund the government for 12 months. Sometimes, tem<span class="word-wrap-span">porspan>ary authorisations are made, but if no new bill is passed before the old one <span class="word-wrap-span">expirespan>s, funding simply dries up. This is not how the process works in other western democracies where the purpose of new bills is often to <span class="word-wrap-span">amendspan> the status <span class="word-wrap-span">quospan>. If <span class="word-wrap-span">Theresaspan> May’s government cannot push through a new Finance Bill, the British government doesn’t stop working; funding simply remains at existing levels (though Mrs May might find herself in a bit of hot water).

Rules over working during funding <span class="word-wrap-span">lapsespan>s has made shutdowns in America more likely. Before a rule change in 1980, government agencies often operated before Congress had <span class="word-wrap-span">approvespan>d the necessary money, assuming that they would get around to approving the cash sooner or later. Then Benjamin Civiletti, Jimmy Carter’s <span class="word-wrap-span">attorneyspan>-general said that this was a violation of US law. The only way to comply was for agencies to not spend the money unless the usage concerned “the safety of human life or the protection of property”; that <span class="word-wrap-span">exemptspan>s select spending by the military, among others. The result was the current type of government shutdown whereby funding actually stops flowing and workers stop working. Mr Civiletti’s creation made funding <span class="word-wrap-span">lapsespan>s <span class="word-wrap-span">harsherspan>, and thus less frequent—but also established their unique place in America’s democracy.

<span class="word-wrap-span">Antipathyspan> towards big government has also played its part. American <span class="word-wrap-span">conservativespan>s have long maintained that a large federal government <span class="word-wrap-span">infringespan>s upon voters’ rights and a free market. <span class="word-wrap-span">Ronaldspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">Reaganspan> quipped that “the nine most terrifying words in the English language are: ‘I’m from the government and I'm here to help.’” Republicans are more willing to close the government than their <span class="word-wrap-span">Democraticspan> <span class="word-wrap-span">counterpartspan>s. This week, YouGov polled 1,500 Americans on behalf of The Economist and found that 38% of Republicans believe that lawmakers should “fight for the priorities that they believe in, even if it means risking a government shutdown,” compared with 25% of Democrats. It seems that Republicans’ <span class="word-wrap-span">negativespan> feelings about Washington may also extend to federal workers: 65% of Democrats have “a great deal” of sympathy for federal government employees who have been <span class="word-wrap-span">furloughspan>ed or are working without pay—compared to 22% of Republicans.

They now have to pay royalties for parts that used to be free; or, if they decide to  a patent, they can no longer be reasonably confident of getting away with it.
